body: “更的应用”

I am also trying installing the R package (w/ GPU support) on OS X EI Capitan. After doing
- disabling Integrity Protection as suggested by @changkun
- set LD_LIBRARY_PATH to include "where the libcudart.7.0.5 is"
- set DYLD_FALLBACK_LIBRARY_PATH to include "where the libcudart.7.0.5 is";  **note that this step may not be mandatory**

I can compile the R package and **a testing running on both CPU and GPU works inside the R sessions initialized in a terminal**.

However, when loading mxnet inside **RStudio** (the latest version), the following error pops up

``` r
> require(mxnet)
Loading required package: mxnet
Error : .onLoad failed in loadNamespace() for 'mxnet', details:
  call: dyn.load(file, DLLpath = DLLpath, ...)
  error: unable to load shared object '/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.2/Resources/library/mxnet/libs/libmxnet.so':
  dlopen(/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.2/Resources/library/mxnet/libs/libmxnet.so, 10): Library not loaded: @rpath/libcudart.7.5.dylib
  Referenced from: /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.2/Resources/library/mxnet/libs/libmxnet.so
  Reason: image not found
```

Any idea on enabling mxnet in **RStudio**? Thanks.

Tried the second approach - compiling the R pkg from source to be able to use GPU in mxnet-R

I have been trying installing the R package (w/ GPU support) on OS X EI Capitan. After doing
- disabling Integrity Protection as suggested by @changkun (see #575)
- set LD_LIBRARY_PATH to include "where the libcudart.7.0.5 is"
- set DYLD_FALLBACK_LIBRARY_PATH to include "where the libcudart.7.0.5 is"; **note that this step may not be mandatory**.

I finally can compile the R package and a testing running on both CPU and GPU works inside the R sessions initialized in a terminal. 

However, the only left issue is that mxnet cannot be loaded inside **RStudio** (the latest version). 

``` r
> require(mxnet)
Loading required package: mxnet
Error : .onLoad failed in loadNamespace() for 'mxnet', details:
  call: dyn.load(file, DLLpath = DLLpath, ...)
  error: unable to load shared object '/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.2/Resources/library/mxnet/libs/libmxnet.so':
  dlopen(/Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.2/Resources/library/mxnet/libs/libmxnet.so, 10): Library not loaded: @rpath/libcudart.7.5.dylib
  Referenced from: /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.2/Resources/library/mxnet/libs/libmxnet.so
  Reason: image not found
```

This is a known issue I met this summer. I think it has been fixed and I can talk about it with Kevin from Rstudio later.

Can you try to run

``` r
Sys.getenv("LD_LIBRARY_PATH")
```

in RStudio and show me the results?

Inside Rstudio

``` r
> Sys.getenv("LD_LIBRARY_PATH")
[1] ""
```

In a contrast, in terminal

``` bash
 echo $LD_LIBRARY_PATH 
/usr/local/cuda/lib:/Users/lchen/cudnn3/cuda/lib:/Developer/NVIDIA/CUDA-7.5/lib:/Users/lchen/torch/install/lib:
```
use shape (1, 1, 64, 64).
Exactly the same problem I met during this summer. I will come back to you later.

You can parse the log to get what you want, which is the way TensorBoard
does in TensorFlow.

This is related to more operator support, to enable larger flexibility. MXNet was developed in an iterative matter, where operator is added when needed. You right that TF has the more operator coverage so far, but you and others can help to make mxnet better :)

The best way to improve this is open an issue for each operator needed, and we can work together to make it happen. This is not hard as imagined and it has been working for most of operators proposed c.f. #404  and other proposed ops, e.g. #215 

For example, if what you asked was dot product of matrix, it is already support by FullyConnected

```
result = FullyConnected(A, B, no_bias=True) ;
```

If you would like to propose something more, open an issue like Support Dot Operator, and propose what was needed, the developers and others will give suggestions on what can be done, usually involves 10 - 100 lines of c++ code, most of which can be copied from template, and once that is added, everyone benefit from your contribution.

Thanks!

This is because in src/io/iter_image_record.cc:248 we are always decoding image to 3 channels with cv::imdecode(buf, 1). For grey images this just duplicate the grey channel 3 times. It shouldn't hurt if you just set your data shape to (3,64,64). 

However, if you do wan't to fix it, you need to replace `res = cv::imdecode(buf, 1);` with `res = cv::imdecode(buf, -1);` and fix the code following that.
It works, thanks. What's the reason for the separation between LeakyReLU and activations?

@piiswrong Ok, I changed the code to use `target_shape` instead.

@winstywang Agreed, that is what I plan to use it for; however, I see two principal issues at the moment:
1. **The lack of automatic shape inference** makes this operator cumbersome to use (and easy to misuse).  I believe the best way forward is to consider a more general shape inference scheme that specifies dependencies explicitly.  This way an operator can state which information it needs to know in order to complete unspecified shape information.  For example, a simple method would be that the caller of `InferShape` can tell whether any change to the shapes have been made.  It calls `InferShape` for all operators repeatedly until no further change happens.  This would allow backpropagation of shape information so that we no longer need the `target_shape` parameter in the `Random` operator.
2. **Parameters in MXNet are currently fixed size, independent of the batch size**.  When implementing something like stochastic variational Bayes we would need one (random) parameter per instance.  I am currently thinking of the best way to implement this in a generic manner.

### Example

An example of how to use the code is

```
import mxnet as mx

R = mx.sym.Random(target_shape=(int(32),), random_type="gaussian")
A = mx.sym.Activation(data=R, act_type="relu")

A_exec = A.bind(ctx=mx.cpu(), args={})
A_exec.forward()
print A_exec.outputs[0].asnumpy()
```
